fields.descriptive_line:
Theatrical ensemble of cloak, two capes, cassock, sash, biretta and boots worn by Sir Henry Irving as Cardinal Wolsey in Henry VIII in 1892, at the Lyceum, under his own management.
[cloak] Voluminous red ribbed silk hooded cloak.
[sash] Long sash of crimson silk (now faded and shattered) tapering to finish in a gold (faded) cotton tassel at each end.
fields.physical_description:
[cloak] Voluminous hooded ribbed silk cloak finishing in pointed train. Unlined and consisting of widths of silk machine sewn together. The edges and hem have been hand rolled. The cloak is gathered into a yoke at the neck, to which the ends of the hood are attached. At the base of the hood is a short, cape which falls around the shoulders and is kept in place by two 'weights'. 
[cape] Red twilled silk semi-circular cape with large round hood. Unlined. Closing at the centre with a row of  23 buttons of which half are functional and half are not, fastening alternately. Most buttons have a crocheted cover, though four replacement buttons have been covered with silk. There two 'weights', one at the front and one at the back.
[sash] Crimson silk sash (now faded and shattering) tapering to gold (faded) tassel at each end.
[cape] Short, red semi circular hooded silk cape, fastening at centre front with five rows of decorative cord and buttons (10 self covered buttons in total). Cape lined with cotton, pointed hood unlined.
[cassock] Red silk cassock with small stand up collar and slight train. Fastening at centre front with vertical row of small self covered buttons. Heavily worn, silk extremely fragile and badly shattered.
51 buttonholes with matching buttons, 3 buttons missing. One further small self covered on the shoulder, by the collar seam. 
A piece of red crepe has been let into the back seam to repair a tear. There is also a narrow red tape at the seam joining the sleeve to the body.
Maker's label in collar-L&H  Nathan, Court & Theatrical, Costumiers, 17 Coventry Street, Piccadilly Circus, London, W.
[biretta] Biretta in red silk. Lined with red silk and red cotton sateen.
[boot] Crimson grosgrain silk boot with rust coloured grosgrain silk ribbons, leather sole.Lined in rough cream linen[?]. Many original repairs. Asymmetrical opening held together by two ribbons tied in bows. A longer, decorative riibon winds around the shoe, eventually tying in a bow at the front (left)
[boot] Crimson grosgrain silk boot with rust coloured grosgrain silk ribbons, leather sole.Lined in rough cream linen[?]. Many original repairs. Asymmetrical opening held together by two ribbons tied in bows. A longer, decorative riibon winds around the shoe, eventually tying in a bow at the front (right)

[cape] Length: 63.5 cm from back of neck to hem, Width: 146 cm maximum width
[sash] Length: 550 cm sash, Width: 22 cm sash
[cape] Length: 43 cm Cape, Length: 44 cm Front point of hood to neck, Width: 94 cm Widest point
[cassock] Length: 236 cm Approx maximum length, collar to end of train
[biretta] Width: 19 cm across top (square), Width: 8 cm Across brim

fields.marks: [cassock] L&H Nathan,/Court & Theatrical/Costumiers,/17 Coventry Street, Piccadilly Circus,/London, W.
fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume as Cardinal Wolsey in Henry VIII by William Shakespeare (1564-1616).  In keeping with leading actors before him, Irving chose the role of the Cardinal for its complex and arresting character, heightened visually by his costume of a vivid pink colour.  Irving’s Wolsey was a mixture of asceticism and malignity, a religious man who rose from humble beginnings to attain a position of great influence as the King’s Lord Chancellor.  It was this, coupled with Wolsey’s eventual loss of power and status, that attracted Irving to the part.   To ensure historical accuracy, Irving employed John Seymour Lucas (1849-1923), a Royal Academician and Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries, to oversee the design of the costumes.

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography:
Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 134.
Describes Irving as Wolsey: "He is swathed from head to foot in what is miscalled the cardinal's scarlet. It is not scarlet at all, but an indescribable geranium-pink, with a dash of vermillion in it. The biretta on the head is of the same blush-rose colour, and it hides every inch of hair, bringing into relief the pale, refined, and highly intellectual face"
Clement Scott (1841-1904) was an influential English theatre critic who wrote for "The Daily Telegraph".
fields.history_note:
Museum of London Register entry: 'returned in September 1960'.
[sash] Museum of London note: 'Holmes wrongly lists this as a 'cincture'.'
